PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Veterans' Affairs Pharmaceutical Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that: The Benefits of the War Widows have been altered, and they no longer receive Pharmaceutical Benefits from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This is causing great concern and hardship, as quite a lot of their medications are no longer available, and there is nothing to replace them on National Health. They are now required to pay large amounts to obtain the medications, just to stay alive.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Honour its commitment to these War Widows by: Returning their Veterans' Affairs Pharmaceutical Benefits to them immediately, and to refrain from worrying these aging widows any further by tampering with our Veterans' Affairs Act and breaking all promises made to our husbands . . .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Charge
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain electors in the seat of Lilley shows-
1. That the Federal Government has given a commitment to the provision of tertiary education for the people of Australia; but
2. That certain aspects of the Higher Education Administration Charge may adversely affect access to tertiary education by some categories of students.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. The Federal Government discontinue the Higher Education Administration Charge as soon as is economically feasible.
2. During the operation of the administration charge, a graduated charge be introduced, the amount of which to be related to the number of units studied, so as to promote greater equity.
3. A set maximum charge be introduced for families to alleviate the burden of such a charge on single income earners with more than one dependent student.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to recognise and respond to the fact that the major difficulties faced by exporters result from its own policies and not from external factors.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Week after week, day after day, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his colleagues in the Government berate the Australian community as to why things are tough in this country. We have heard repeatedly the cry that it was the Fraser-Anthony Government; we have heard constantly that it is the result of actions taken abroad. The reality is that whether it is in this place or whether it is at meetings such as that of the Australian Finance Industry Council-where the Prime Minister pursued the same line-the Prime Minister and his Ministers are misleading the Australian people. They are pursuing a policy which ignores the prime relationship between economic management in Australia and the returns for those who produce the goods and particularly those who sell and export. Indeed, there is little doubt about the statement the other day by Joe de Bruin of the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association-that well known affiliate of some honourable members; that factional colleague of those who sit in the corner of the Labor benches-when he said that the last four years had seen the most sustained reduction in living standards since the Depression of the 1930s and with the economy in its present state there was no relief in sight. Sadly, not only is there no relief in sight, but also the connection between our gross external debt and declining exports, on the one hand, and the living standards of Australians, on the other, is totally ignored by the Government and most of those who speak on its behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that the ballooning overseas debt is not purely a product of our declining terms of trade. But I find it quite incredible that when month after month we learn that billions of dollars and, in more recent times, millions of dollars deficit are incurred, we are told that it is really not a bad figure. There is an illusion that because the stock market is buoyant, the average producer is getting on quite well. That is arrant nonsense. The reason for raising this matter of public importance today is to try to ensure that those factors that are contributing to the appalling state of the terms of trade of the Australian family farmer, the appalling state of the Australian small business man and the declining conditions for average Australians, reflected by that comment of Joe de Bruin, are understood in the wider community. The fault lies not in what happened in the previous coalition Government or in what is happening abroad, it lies predominantly in what is not happening in Australia or what is happening as a result of this big spending, big taxing Labor Government.

Above all, we need to understand that while there are external problems created by changing world market circumstances-and I will say a little about that in a moment-those problems were inadequately addressed by this Government, particularly in the early stages of its administration. When my colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt) asked the Prime Minister only yesterday whether he would play some role in the renegotiation of the beef arrangements with Japan, the Prime Minister gave no recognition of the fact that Australia's share of the Japanese beef market is declining and the United States share is increasing largely because of the neglect of the first Labor Minister for Trade, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) back in 1984. There is a total failure to understand the affront caused by sending a junior Minister, such as the present Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) or the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), to a country such as Japan. The Japanese treat that with something like contempt. The Americans send their Vice President and the Vice President is the second most senior member of the American Administration. The Prime Minister said that he was really quite concerned and he would like to go to Japan, `but . . . '. The reality is that unless we equal status with the Japanese community, our chances of overcoming what looks like a sweetheart deal between Prime Minister Nakasone and President Reagan is minimal indeed.

Let me emphasise the fact that there is a direct link between market access for Australians exporters and prices paid for Australian exports, and living standards in this country. It is important that at every level this Government should understand that both in its attempt to try to negate the efforts by the Americans to add to their subsidies against imports and its attempts to try to maximise Australian access in markets such as Japan, the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and every senior member of the Government should be involved. We have the farcical situation in which someone whom most of us do not even know-I think he is the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham)-is leading a major delegation from this Parliament to try to persuade members of the United States Congress that their present legislation is not in Australia's interests. Let me try to persuade the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister that these other figures in their Government do not count. I see that the honourable member for McMillan has just walked into the House. For him to try to persuade members of the American Congress that the steps they are taking through the Gephardt amendment and in their protectionist legislation should, for some reason, be changed is really quite farcical. I think that it is a great pity that the Government does not lift its performance in international trade negotiations.

Of course, we are concerned about the circumstances in which the United States and Japan are introducing an increasing wave of protectionism. On this side of the House at every level we will do all we can to assist those positive attempts by the Government to try to do something to reverse those legislative and administrative trends. But it must be understood that the Government must also play its part and that it is not doing so adequately at the moment.

When we look at the situation in Australia we find that again the Government has no basic understanding of the components of Australia's export income. Primary and mineral exports are still the prime source of Australia's export trade. We just heard a speech from the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) telling us all the efforts that were being made on behalf of tourism. That is to be commended, but we need to understand that tourism is a very small part of gaining Australia's export earnings. Primary and mineral exports remain predominant. In Question Time today we heard an incredible attack by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on Opposition members and the Australian Democrats because they are opposed to the Government's petroleum resource rent tax. I do not know whether the Treasurer understands, but as at 28 February this year, 38 of Australia's 43 on-shore drilling rigs were idle, as were three of the four drilling vessels and 19 of the 20 seismic crews. The Australian Bureau of Statistics issued figures a couple of weeks ago showing that petroleum exploration spending had dropped from $342m in the first half of last year to $157m in the second half-a drop of 54 per cent. This is the industry on which the Treasurer intends to levy a new resource rental tax, a tax that the industry does not want and cannot afford. This tax will add to the cost of not only every motorist in Australia, but also every producer. For that reason members of the National and Liberal parties will continue to oppose an unwanted, unnecessary, unjustified tax.

Indeed, we need to understand that in Australia today the current marginal Government take on oil found before 1975 is 91 per cent. The take on new discoveries is 69.4 per cent under the resources rent tax legislation and 71 per cent under the new oil excise. That compares with marginal rates of 45 per cent in the United States and only 39 per cent in Canada. That comparison shows why it is quite objectionable for this Government to come to this House, pretend it is concerned with exports and the productive industries, and apply new levels of taxation. Our tax imposition is totally unsatisfactory at every level of business. All one needs to do is look at the 1986 Mount Isa Mines report, where one will find that company tax this year is $1.4m but the new fringe benefits tax imposed by this Government is $5m. What is this Government doing? It is introducing new taxes, such as a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax, and denying the new mining operations any chance of playing their proper part in exporting the products that are so necessary for Australia's domestic recovery. The Australian Coal Association tells me that not only is there a problem with government taxes, there is also a problem with government regulations. In the exploration, development, production and transport to the point of export of coal in Australia, 28 State government departments are involved in the State of New South Wales and nearly half the Federal Departments.

We all know that in terms of inflation we are falling further and further behind. Indeed, Mr J. B. Ritchie wrote to the Australian Financial Review earlier this week and said that the extent to which inflation in Australia is rising had eroded almost totally the competitive advantage of the Australian depreciation. That is the situation: Inflation, interest rates, regulation and taxation-all imposed by this Government, all at non-competitive levels and all making it almost impossible for exporters to play their part. As for the poor old family farmer, he has been driven out the back door. That has occurred for several reasons. The first is that all the factors that I mentioned a moment ago, such as interest rates and inflation, apply at least as much to the farmer as to anyone else. The family farmer cannot go out on to the wider market and borrow funds; he must borrow from traditional lending sources. When he is trying to buy agricultural machinery or fund the acquisition of livestock he is forced to pay in accordance with an interest rate regime that is at least three times as high as that of our competitors and under an inflation rate that is at least twice as high.

One of the fundamental reasons why I have raised this matter of public importance this afternoon is that the Government has failed to understand that it has been totally inadequate in taking any steps to reduce those work practices that are totally frustrating for everyone involved in every industry in Australia, particularly those who are involved in export. It was not that long ago that we heard from Mr Charles Copeman from Peko Wallsend. He started the move to try to get changed those work practices at Robe River affecting the mining industry. Honourable members would remember that the work practices in question involved such things as the requirement of two operators, not one, for each loader or bulldozer at the port. Only one operator could work at one time so the other operator spent half of each shift in the crib room. At the mines three water trucks were required on the day shift, even in winter or when it was raining. Full equipment crews were required in the mine at all times, whether or not they were working. Even if no shovels were operating, minimum manning requirements meant that if a rostered operator was off sick another had to be called in-at a minimum of four hours on double time when no work was being done. The company's messing officers were not allowed keys to the company stores. Yet, this Government has the hide to criticise Charles Copeman and others who have tried to bring about a fundamental change in Australia's industrial practices. But just as bad, if not worse, are those industrial practices pursued on Australian wharves. Earlier this week in response to a question that I asked, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) showed his total lack of understanding of the appalling non-competitiveness of the handling of grain in the Australian grain terminals.

I draw to the attention of all honourable members an excellent article headed `Why our grain exports are in turmoil', written by Julian Cribb and published in the Australian news- paper of Tuesday 5 May. Figures in relation to the days delayed-relating to average annual delays, 1981-85-are based on claims agreed after applying deductibles, with the exclusion of crew strikes, and they indicate that Australia tops the list around the world. In percentage terms, 26.5 work hours were lost due to industrial strikes. On average, 140.3 days per annum are lost in Australian industry, as compared with a country like Papua New Guinea which loses an average of only 6.06 days per annum and New Zealand, which loses some 10.38 days per annum. More importantly, the average throughput of grain per employee at Sydney terminal is just 17,000 tonnes a year compared to 80,000 tonnes a man at Convent and Westwago in the United States of America and 120,000 tonnes at Kalama in the United States. How can Australia compete when work practices like that are pursued? We need to understand that the average personal income of a family grain farmer over the past two years, of just $580 a year, stands in stark contrast to the average wage paid at the Sydney grain terminal of $30,900. The whole circumstances of work in the export industries is appalling.

It is in this climate that the Government must look at its own soul. It is not the fault of the Fraser-Anthony Government; it is not the fault of what is happening in the United States Congress; it is not the fault of what is happening in Japan; it is the product of a Labor accord between the present Government and the trade union movement. It is the product of an inadequate response by this Government to industrial conditions that are totally unsatisfactory. It is a product of economic policies which have led to quite impossible levels of interest rates. It is the product of Government taxation-and I refer to the resource rental tax, the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, which are anti-production and which are against the interests of small productive Australians. Unless the Government wakes up to the reality that those circumstances must change, the opportunity for us ever to defeat the declining living standards, referred to by Mr Joe de Bruin, are absolutely nil. The only way to change those conditions is to change the Government and with it to change the economic policies that the Government is presently pursuing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This poor, embattled and befuddled leader of an embattled and divided party sits here overshadowed by a septuagenarian demagogue in Queensland. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) has just made a speech which exposes the confusion in not only his mind but the minds of those in the divided Opposition. The honourable member started off by saying-and this is also evident in his motion-that all our problems are due to domestic circumstances, and then the right honourable member proceeded to spend a good deal of his time talking about what was happening to our beef market in Japan, what was happening in the United States, and about what was happening between Japan and the United States. They are some of the international circumstances about which we are concerned but with which we have been dealing more effectively than any other government. If the Leader of the National Party of Australia really wants to go back to where the trouble started in relation to the Japanese beef market, I ask him to review what his former leader did during the 1977 negotiations. However, the right honourable member prefers to criticise the very effective negotiations that were undertaken by my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of the Japanese market, we still enjoy a much more favourable position for quota beef than does the United States. But it is interesting to hear a contribution made by at least one member of the Opposition on the question of trade, because for months and months we have sat here in despair and wondered when the Opposition would outline a policy in relation to trade and exports generally. All we have heard has been an almost weekly cry from various members of the National Party to send yet another delegation to the United States. That has been their only policy, namely, send a delegation to the United States. What on earth would a delegation do in the United States if it were not to address the international circumstances confronting Australia? Honourable members opposite have had only one policy and that was doing something about American policy, and then they come in here with this proposition saying that the whole of our problems are related to domestic circumstances.

Further on the matter of these cries being made for delegations to be sent overseas, over a period of time the Deputy Leader of the National Party made nine separate calls for a delegation to go to the United States. The former spokesman on trade made eight separate calls for delegations; indeed his best effort was to make four calls in four days for a delegation to go to the United States. When the Government does respond recognising that now is an appropriate time to send in a low key and non-hysterical way a group of members of this House, and one from the Senate, to the United States to talk to counterparts in the United States Congress, all that members opposite can do is to disparage the leader of the delegation, who was a member of the last successful delegation and someone who is highly respected in the agricultural community for the work that he has done on behalf of the agricultural community. I think that to disparage this delegation even before it has left Australia, the delegation which has been the centrepiece, indeed, the only plank in the Opposition's trade policy, is a deliberate attempt to undermine its effectiveness when it gets to the United States. If that is really the attitude of the National Party to this delegation, why do not National Party members withdraw from it? Of course those members want to be on it; they want to go on a weekly delegation. All they are interested in is tripping off to the United States, rather than making some concerted effort towards policy development in this difficult area.

That delegation will be followed by my own visit to the United States so that we can have a two-pronged approach to the problems confronting us with a belligerent and increasingly protectionist Congress. So, this delegation will talk to members of Congress and then I will follow it up a few days later to maximise our efforts in that regard. It is very curious that the Leader of the National Party should make this deliberate attempt to undermine the efforts of this delegation, a delegation of which his Party's Deputy Leader will be a member, before it has even left Australia.

Let me agree with the Leader of the National Party on one matter, and that is when he refers to some of the domestic circumstances confronting our industry. Let us look at the circumstances confronting the Queensland coal industry. Coal remains our largest export. It is absolutely vital for us to continue to have a prosperous coal industry, one which can compete in the world. That industry confronts difficult times. There is massively increased competition from other countries for the existing coal markets around the world. Those coal markets are not expanding very fast, but the competition is expanding extraordinarily fast. As a result of that competition, prices for Australian coal are dramatically down. There has never been a more important time when we should be addressing the difficulties within that industry to try to improve its efficiency, productivity and overall competitiveness so that it can hang on to the important markets that it has around the world.

This is a responsibility which lies with both employers and employees. The Australian Coal Consultative Council involves both sides of the industry, which would not even sit in the same room when we came to office, so sour were the relations between employers and employees, largely as a result of the neglect of the former Leader of the National Party. We have been able to get the various sides of that industry-the employers, the employees and the various governments of the States in which those industries operate-together to try to address some of the difficulties that confront it. They have had a series of meetings, and I have attended several of them. They have all been thoroughly productive in terms of seriously dealing with some of the difficulties which confront that industry and the kind of change which confronts it. I have said to the employees as well as to the employers, the managers, that they will all have to improve their game; they will all have to improve the way in which they work; they will all have to work to improve the industrial relations within that industry, which, of course, has not been very favourable in recent times.

We will not deal with that by taking the attitude of Charles Copeman. He instituted a lockout in one of our other vital export industries, the iron ore industry. What do honourable members think was the attitude in Japan when the mining company decided to lock out the work force and suspend exports to Japan, a most important market for us and one which has to be supplied reliably if we are to be looked upon as a serious supplier of iron ore? Of course the Japanese were totally confused by that action which was very unnecessary. Since that time, since that heroic and massively unsuccessful gesture on behalf of Mr Copeman, the unions have been prepared to sit down and work their way through some of those outdated practices. We cannot blame the unions alone for the existence of those practices. During the period of the former Government there was a very lazy and complacent attitude to the circumstances confronting the mining industry. Just because prices were high, management gave in and granted extraordinary conditions which should never have been accepted. Most of those mad work practices which are now being reversed were agreed to. They were accepted by management. It did not even resist them. What sort of an attitude is that for management to take? It is now paying the price for it because the circumstances in those industries are not as favourable and they are having to wind back some of the conditions.

In this difficult situation what do we see the Queensland Government now doing? It has introduced a piece of legislation which is quite calculated and quite deliberately intended not to solve the problem of industrial disputation in the coal industry but to inflame it. The real purpose of that Queensland legislation is to cause, not stop, a strike. We have this crazed megalomaniac, Bjelke-Petersen, out of control simply with a politically inspired campaign directed at the heart of our most important export industry. The Leader of the National Party is right; there is a great domestic threat to one of our great export industries, and it comes from his Party in Queensland. That is the most serious threat to our export performance at the moment. It is quite deliberately designed to cause strikes when we should be ensuring that we have increased reliability within our coal industry.

The Leader of the National Party indicated that some sweetheart deals may be being done between Prime Minister Nakasone and President Reagan. One of the areas of great concern to us is that maybe the Japanese will buy more coal from the United States. Would it not be a wonderful excuse for the Japanese to divert their sources of supply if our coal industry went on strike? If it went on strike that would give the Japanese the excuse they want to divert their sources of supply. This has been done quite deliberately by a lunatic in Queensland in the party of the Leader of the National Party who comes in here and tries to say that we are responsible for the problems confronting exporters in this country.

I want to make another point about this. The silence of the coal companies in Queensland is quite intolerable. I know that they have been threatened; they have been intimidated by the Queensland Premier with threats in relation to coal levies and rail freights to keep their mouths shut, to not express the view that they otherwise would express about this mad legislation. They are opposed to it; they know what a threat it represents to the stability of their industry, yet they are being threatened by the Queensland Premier that if ever they should voice any criticism of it the levies will go up and the freight rates will go up-levies and freight rates which, of course, are already a punitive tax on the coal industry in Queensland, ripping something like $90m out of the industry, not in respect of any services provided by the Queensland Government but just as a straight, blatant tax. He is threatening to put them up if those coal companies ever step out of line. Those coal companies cannot afford the luxury of their silence. They have to expose the threat which this legislation represents not only to their industry but also to the whole of the Australian economy.

Indeed, it ill becomes the Opposition here to maintain its silence because it knows what this is all about and it ought to have the courage to expose this campaign for what it is. The Government would not under any circumstances condone any industrial relations action in this matter. We are working with the unions, and with the industry if it is prepared, to find ways of defeating this legislation-and defeat it we must because, as I said, it is not designed to stop strikes; it is designed to start strikes and threaten our great coal exporting industry.

Let me deal with a couple of blatantly incorrect facts which were represented to the House by the Leader of the National Party. In the first instance, he quoted the circumstances of our agricultural industries. Of course they have been badly affected, not by the policies of this Government but by the international market-place. The price of wheat has halved, but we did not halve it; the Americans and the Europeans did. We have not disrupted the sugar market; that has happened as a result of European policies. Nevertheless, as a result of the devaluation which flowed from the floating of the Australian dollar, a policy which even the alleged farmers' friends could not get through, the farmers have been saved.

If we look at farm cash operating surpluses, which is the normal measure to establish the conditions of Australian farms, we find that in 1986-87 the average surplus across the sector is expected to increase by 30 per cent following a fall of 12 per cent in 1985-86. We know that that does not make farmers well off, but it is quite incorrect for the Leader of the National Party to say that their circumstances are continuing to deteriorate. There have been rises of 140 per cent in sugar and 105 per cent in beef. There have been improvements in farm operating surpluses of 100 per cent in relation to sheep, 97 per cent in cotton, 44 per cent in relation to sheep-beef and even 13 per cent in wheat. The Leader of the National Party has exposed a total misunderstanding, a total ignorance, of the circumstances which we currently confront.

Another fact which is worth putting on record is that we now enjoy in this country a very substantially improved competitiveness, not only as a result of the depreciation of the dollar but also as a result of improvements in our wage structure. If we compare our unit labour costs with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average we find that we are now 25 to 30 per cent more competitive than we were 2 1/2 years ago. The Leader of the National Party went on about a whole lot of other issues that he alleged we have not addressed. Our record on removing impediments to trade has been infinitely better than anything that he and his colleagues ever did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the National Health Act 1953, the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954. The purpose of this Bill is to enable the introduction of new recurrent funding arrangements for nursing homes, quality of care standards in nursing homes and improved arrangements for granting capital assistance to non-profit organisations. These measures will improve the quality of care and quality of life provided for aged people and achieve greater efficiency in government funding of nursing homes.

Over the last decade, and over the past five years in particular, major criticisms have been made of many aspects of policy and program management in the aged care area, and in particular residential care. There have been two major reports to Parliament by committees comprising representatives of both sides of politics. One was by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, the McLeay report, and the other was by the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, the Giles report. There has also been a report by the Auditor-General on an efficiency audit of the Commonwealth administration of nursing home programs. All these made strong comments about the inappropriate mix of services between and within institutional accommodation and home and community care, the unplanned and unco-ordinated approach to residential care provision, the need for significantly tightened control on the growth of nursing homes, and the need to introduce funding arrangements which provide incentives to operators to be efficient and reduce inequities between States. The often inadequate quality of resident care, the need for more consistent inspection and better quality control arrangements and the crucial roles of assessment and rehabilitation were also highlighted in these reports.

Against this background, in its February 1983 pre-election policy statement, the Australian Labor Party committed itself to a change in the approach to funding of nursing homes, foreshadowing the introduction of a program grants approach. The Review of Nursing Homes and Hostels, which was tabled by my predecessor, former Senator Don Grimes, in the Senate on 14 April 1986, brought together the conclusions and recommendations of these previous reports and outlined a blueprint for a staged program of reform of residential care services for aged people. As the first stage of the reform program, the Government made a significant commitment, in the 1986-87 Budget, to begin the process of redistributing resources for the care of aged people away from nursing homes to alternative less institutionalised forms of residential care and to community care services. This will involve, as a package, additional expenditure of approximately $24m in 1986-87, $80m in 1987-88 and $150m in 1988-89.

Implementation of that first stage is now well under way. The main elements include new needs-based planning arrangements linked to capital funds arrangements covering both nursing homes and hostels, with increasing emphasis on the number of hostel places through an expanded capital program; increased resources for home and community care; the development of a special services program to cater for the special needs of frail aged people which cannot satisfactorily be met through standard levels of funding; and the development of co-ordinated assessment processes, including the staged establishment and expansion of assessment teams, to assist aged people and their families to plan the most appropriate care to meet their particular needs.

The Government also foreshadowed in the 1986-87 Budget the introduction of new recurrent funding arrangements for nursing homes and arrangements to develop quality of care and life standards in nursing homes. On 31 March 1987 I announced the second stage of the Government's program of reform which, with the passage of this Bill, will see the foreshadowed arrangements turned into reality. In developing the proposals to be given effect to by this Bill, the Government has acknowledged that the achievement of improved care services for the aged depends on the co-operation and support of the community, the industry and other groups. For this reason, the Commonwealth has undertaken extensive consultations concerning the details of proposed changes with State governments, the nursing homes and hostels industry, consumer and other welfare groups, and professional and staff organisations.

I shall now discuss the two major elements of reform, commencing with the new nursing home recurrent funding arrangements. Briefly, the new nursing home funding arrangements which this Bill will bring into effect involve the phased introduction, from 1 July 1987, of standard daily resident fees and standard Commonwealth benefits to replace the current cost reimbursement arrangements operating for non-government nursing homes for aged people. These new funding arrangements will constitute a uniform national system. Special conditions will not be granted to one State which are not available to others. These new arrangements will apply to some 1,250 non-government homes caring for some 60,000 aged residents across Australia-those being private participating homes funded under the National Health Act 1953, including both `for profit' and `not for profit homes' and `not for profit' homes funded under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. While ostensibly these groups of homes are funded under two different types of funding arrangements, both are essentially funded on a cost reimbursement basis.

Under the new arrangements the Commonwealth will, in effect, fund a specified level of service of nursing home care on behalf of residents at a predetermined price. It will no longer reimburse proprietors for whatever level of costs has been incurred. In other words, emphasis will be placed on outcomes rather than inputs. This represents a vast improvement over the current arrangements which are unsatisfactory for a number of reasons. First, residents of participating nursing homes can be faced with unexpected fee increases every few months. Many are required to pay amounts significantly above the minimum contribution, even though the standard of care may be no better than that provided in other nursing homes where the residents pay only the minimum contribution. Second, cost savings by efficient nursing home proprietors do not produce increased profits and there is therefore no incentive to operate efficiently. Third, the industry is also subject to an excessive degree of regulation and unwarranted operational rigidities. In order to maintain their financial viability, proprietors need to apply for a fee increase whenever their costs vary and provide detailed documentation in support of their applications. Fourth, the quantum of Commonwealth nursing home benefits is geared to the levels of expenditure incurred by nursing homes. Because costs vary widely between homes and States, this system has led to substantial per capita inequities in benefits paid from one State to another. For example, the maximum benefit paid to ordinary care residents in participating nursing homes varies from $54.60 a day in Victoria to $35.25 a day in Queensland. Fifth, the plethora of different funding, and funding control mechanisms, and their seeming inability to contain the mushrooming cost of nursing home accommodation, have resulted in totally unacceptable and unjustified cost escalations per bed day. In the period from 1973 to 1985, for example, the increase in Commonwealth per bed day expenditure was of the order of 606 per cent, compared with a 233 per cent increase in the consumer price index and a 308 per cent movement in average weekly earnings. The cost of nursing home care has clearly risen out of all proportion to other indicators and it is becoming increasingly difficult to prevent unscrupulous proprietors from exploiting the system to increase profits at the expense of residents and taxpayers.

The unintended and undesirable consequences of the present funding system are well illustrated by the findings of an analysis done by the Department of Community Services of nursing home operating costs incurred during the 1984-85 financial year. The study concentrated particularly on infrastructure costs-that is, all costs other than those incurred on nursing and personal care staff. This analysis confirmed that there is extraordinary diversity in the nature and quantum of funding approved by the Department around Australia for the provision of infrastructure services-State average infrastructure costs vary by 27 per cent and are 18 per cent higher in Victorian homes than the next highest State, South Australia. The analysis also showed no statistically significant relationships between infrastructure costs and factors which might explain these substantial variations in costs such as dependency levels, bed capacity, ward size, age of home, whether the home was free standing or part of a complex. Even within States, there are large inexplicable cost variations between individual homes.

The inescapable conclusion drawn from this analysis is that the substantial variations in infrastructure costs both within and between States are unjustified and that there is little basis for having different levels of infrastructure funding from home to home or State to State. This is not to imply blame on individuals, particular sectors or particular States. Clearly it is the funding system itself that is wrong and requires change. Where the funding arrangement leads to the incurring of unwarranted additional costs, it is the taxpayer and the consumer, in the main, who pay the piper. In this particular case, the consumers are frail, elderly people, approximately 80 per cent of whom are in receipt of part of full pensions.

The Government cannot ignore the fact that if there is unnecessarily high expenditure on nursing homes for the very small proportion of aged people in nursing homes, this will mean diminished funding available for less intensive accommodation or community based services for the remainder of the aged population. Clearly, the Government would be negligent if it continued to let costs mushroom in the nursing homes area and thwart its objectives of providing aged people with a wider range of care choices to match more closely their individual needs.

The new funding arrangements for nursing homes being introduced in this Bill are designed specifically to redress the many problems faced under present arrangements and to achieve greater equity between States and individual nursing homes in the Commonwealth funding of aged care. They will also simplify the administration of the program and eliminate the detailed intrusion by the Commonwealth into everyday decisions of care providers about how to spend their infrastructure resources. This will give providers greater flexibility and incentives to increase efficiency, provided that appropriate care and lifestyle outcomes are achieved for residents. Finally, the new arrangements will provide much needed control over the growth of Commonwealth nursing home expenditure.

As I mentioned earlier, the concept of the new funding arrangements is a simple one of introducing, over five annual steps from 1 July 1987 to 1 July 1991, a system of standard fees and benefits for nursing homes catering exclusively or predominantly for aged people. It is proposed that from 1 July 1987, all nursing home fees will be split into two components-one for all direct nursing and personal care costs, and the other for infrastructure costs-for example, transport, laundry, food et cetera-and return on investment. This latter composite infrastructure component is know as the standard aggregated module, or SAM, and represents about 45 per cent of total average nursing home costs.

At this stage, the standard aggregated module will be the only component in respect of which all nursing homes for the aged will begin a gradual transition to a uniform national funding level from 1 July 1987. Until new national uniform staffing standards are agreed with State governments and, indeed, for some time after they are introduced, current approved nursing and personal care staffing levels will continue to be reflected in fees on a cost-reimbursement basis.

The level of SAM is set in the Bill at $27.65 per occupied bed day, for 1987-88. This figure represents the average infrastructure cost for all participating homes for 1984-85 indexed by a weighted average of actual and projected movements in average weekly earnings and consumer price index to give a figure for 1987-88. The Bill also provides for the Minister to either gazette a higher amount or to gazette a formula in accordance with which a higher amount would be ascertained. The formula will provide that in 1988-89 and in subsequent years, the SAM will be indexed by a weighted average of the annual expected movements in the AWE and CPI indices. The index will also take into account the difference between the expected movements in these indices used to determine the previous year's SAM, and the actual movements. The Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notice would be subject to parliamentary disallowance.

In response to requests from industry organisations, the Government has agreed to regular reviews of the appropriateness of the level of SAM, based on surveys of industry costs. I should stress, however, that the level of SAM which has been set for 1987-88 is fixed and non-negotiable. It has been reached after extensive analysis by my Department of nursing home costings data and represents a level which will result in an equitable redistribution of current levels of income within the participating sector. It will also provide a greater level of income than the average infrastructure cost for homes in the deficit financed sector and put them on the same footing as participating homes.

I should stress again that the new funding arrangements represent a transition to a uniform system. Nursing homes with infrastructure costs which are presently either above or below the SAM, will have that component of their fees adjusted in five annual steps to bring them into line with the SAM on a national basis. The 65 per cent of non-government homes which have infrastructure costs below the SAM will receive additional funding over the transition period to assist in improving their quality of care.

The 35 per cent of nursing homes which have a level of infrastructure costs above the SAM will need to bring their outlays on such items more into line with costs in the majority of homes. However, the phasing of this transition over five annual steps will allow such adjustment to be undertaken gradually to ensure that disruption to the industry and to nursing home residents is kept to an absolute minimum.

For higher cost homes whose residents may prefer, and are prepared to pay for, higher quality and more expensive services, the Government has given in-principle support for the concept of fee exemption. This would involve exemption of entire nursing homes or some beds in nursing homes from the standard fee arrangements and allowing those particular homes to charge at levels higher than the standard fee arrangements. The Commonwealth benefit for these beds would be reduced in proportion to the extent to which the fee charged exceeded the regulated fee. In return for greater operating freedom under the exemption arrangements, the Government will be looking for an increased acceptance of responsibility by the proprietors of such homes. To this end, the exemption arrangements are likely to involve careful assessment of the suitability of proprietors, including an assessment of the quality of care and quality of life that a home has afforded to residents under the standard fee arrangements. The exemption concept will be developed for introduction as soon as is practicable.

The Bill contains formulae for calculating the standard ordinary care fee for each nursing home, and a description of the elements which make up the formulae, including nursing and personal care costs and SAM. The Bill provides for the various elements of the formulae to be determined in accordance with gazetted legislative principles, which are subject to parliamentary disallowance.

The Bill also requires the standard ordinary care fee for a nursing home to be taken into account when setting a scale of fees which may be charged by a nursing home. Other matters which will be taken into account in setting a scale of fees will be covered in the principles, and it is envisaged that these matters will include arrangements for ensuring accurate cost reimbursement of nursing and personal care staff costs and for phasing out the charging of different scales of fees within the one nursing home. The current system of temporary fee loadings will continue.

Existing appeal rights in relation to the determination of a scale of fees based on all 1986-87 cost will be preserved and in future proprietors will continue to be able to request a review of decisions relating to the inclusion of nursing and personal care staffing costs within their scale of fees. Such review requests will be required to be made within 42 days of receipt of advice of a decision in relation to a fee application.

The new funding arrangements for nursing homes will provide a greater degree of protection for financially disadvantaged people and will ensure that the group has better access to nursing home care than under existing arrangements. At present, some 80 per cent of residents in all nursing homes are required to pay no more than the minimum resident contribution of 87.5 per cent of the basic pension and rental assistance. This minimum resident contribution will remain at this rate in all nursing homes. The Bill also provides for the Commonwealth to continue to meet the full difference between the approved fees for former deficit-funded nursing homes and the fixed resident contribution relating to those homes which is 87.5 per cent of the basic pension and rental assistance. The residents of other nursing homes pay additional fees of up to $65 per day over and above the minimum resident contribution. By the end of the transition period, the new arrangements will have greatly reduced, for many residents of these homes, the amount to be paid over the minimum resident contribution and will have provided better protection against operating cost increases. Under current arrangements the maximum level of nursing home benefit is adjusted each November. However, because adjustments to SAM are to be made from 1 July each year, the Commonwealth proposes also to adjust the level of the maximum Commonwealth benefit from that date, commencing this year.

The Bill also provides for special administrative arrangements to be introduced which will maintain equity between the way existing and new nursing homes are treated. Under these arrangements, the infrastructure fee component for new nursing homes which received an approval-in-principle before 1 April 1987 and which commence operation between 1 July 1987 and 1 July 1991 will be set under the same transition arrangements to SAM as existing homes. For new homes resulting from approvals-in-principle granted on or after 1 April 1987, the infrastructure fee component for the home or beds will be the SAM. The Bill provides for similar transition provisions in relation to proprietors who rebuild sub-standard nursing homes to improve the living environment and quality of life of residents. This provision applies where approval to rebuild is either granted or sought before 1 July 1987.

Another measure is the inclusion in the Bill of a simple mechanism under the National Health Act 1953 for approving the demolition of premises occupied by a nursing home and the reconstruction of those premises on the same site. The Government intends also to introduce a similar mechanism for approving the relocation of existing nursing home beds as soon as possible. I should make it clear, however, that decisions in relation to relocation proposals will continue to involve an assessment of the appropriateness of the proposal in terms of planning and other objectives.

The Bill also provides that until 1 July 1988, `approved services' in the former deficit-funded sector provided to persons who are not nursing home residents, that is hostel and community residents, will continue to be funded as at present on a cost reimbursement basis. From 1 July 1988, funding for these services will be transferred to the special services program which former Senator Grimes announced as a result of the 1986-87 Budget and will be provided on a grant basis. This does not mean that nursing home residents will cease to receive therapeutic and rehabilitation services-these types of services will be in the future, and indeed have been for many residents in participating nursing homes in the past, largely provided as part of normal nursing home care. Nursing home residents with extraordinary disabilities may also be entitled to supplementary services under the special services program to meet particularly intensive service needs unable to be met under standard funding arrangements.

As I mentioned previously, the new nursing home funding arrangements apply only to nursing homes catering principally for aged people. This Bill provides for the new arrangements to be funded only under the National Health Act 1953, and transfers to that Act the approvals of all nursing homes for aged people approved under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. In line with this transfer of all homes for the aged to the National Health Act 1953, the Bill contains transitional provisions to preserve the general rights and entitlements of transferred homes. The Bill also amends the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974, so that it applies only to nursing homes where the majority of residents are disabled people who are less than 70 years of age. This amendment is reflected in a change to the long title of the Act.

The existing funding arrangements for the 69 nursing homes throughout Australia which cater principally for the non-aged disabled are to be preserved, pending development of a new system for funding these homes consistent with the principles and objectives of the Disability Services Act 1986. The Bill provides for the 69 non-aged homes to be identified in gazette notices published under the National Health Act 1953 and the amending Act. The Bill also enables a certificate of approval-in-principle for new or additional nursing home beds for non-aged disabled people to be granted under either the National Health Act 1953 or the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. New bed numbers for these people will not be subject to the statutory growth control arrangements which apply to nursing home beds for the aged, but will be announced by the Minister each year in the Budget context.

I turn now to the other component of the new funding arrangements-nursing and personal care costs-and to the issue of standards of life and care in nursing homes. I intend, as soon as possible, to introduce uniform national staffing standards based on a resident classification system which reflects different levels of intensity of service need. However, before these uniform national staffing standards are finalised, there will be extensive consultation with service providers, staff and professional bodies and consumer bodies. The new uniform staffing arrangements will incorporate measures to ensure that the new standards will not apply for two years in respect of persons who are resident at the time of introduction. For these residents, the pre-existing approved nursing and personal care staffing levels will continue to apply for that two-year transitional period.

A significant concession made by the Government in the course of consultations with the industry in relation to the new arrangements, has been the inclusion of payroll tax and workers' compensation insurance costs for all staff in the cost-reimbursed nursing and personal care component of the fee. The Government acknowledges, however, that with the management flexibility introduced under standard grant arrangements, there are increased incentives to cut corners to make profits at the expense of standards of care and the quality of life of nursing home residents. It also acknowledges the criticisms of parliamentary reports which have identified serious deficiencies in the quality of care provided in certain nursing homes. To tackle these concerns, the Government is approaching the problem on two fronts.

The Government's first task has been to clarify the standards of care to be required in nursing homes. The Commonwealth, in consultation with the States, has now developed new outcome standards relating to quality of care and quality of life for residents in nursing homes and has prepared a document which incorporates extensive contributions from service providers, unions and professional groups, consumer bodies and many others. The amendments included in this Bill will allow the gazettal of these standards for nursing home care under the National Health Act 1953 as the basis against which the care provided in individual nursing homes can be measured. In implementing the new standards, the Government intends to adopt an educative and consultative role. An amount of $600,000 will be provided over three years for training packages aimed at directors of nursing homes and hostel supervisors. Where sub-standard care is occurring, departmental staff will work with nursing homes to ensure that the welfare of residents is protected, and to improve overall standards as quickly as possible.

The second task is to introduce effective measures to ensure that the minority of nursing homes which have a consistent record of providing poor quality care and which have shown a disinclination to comply with Commonwealth efforts to improve care standards do not continue to do so. The principal existing sanction currently available to the Commonwealth is to withdraw approval of the nursing home, but applying this is difficult because of the immediate need to find alternative care for a large group of frail aged residents if a home is closed.

As the current provisions for dealing with cases of sub-standard care have not proven to be flexible enough, the Bill includes two additional powers which the Commonwealth can use to protect the interests of frail elderly residents, where the gazetted standards of care are not complied with. First, the Bill will enable the Minister to ensure that Commonwealth funding is not provided in respect of any new residents admitted to the nursing home which refuses to comply with standards. The withholding of Commonwealth funding in these circumstances is intended to act as a disincentive for proprietors to admit new residents, with the result that, at the very least, no further elderly people will be subjected to the poor quality care being provided in the home. The second power in the Bill will apply only in relation to nursing homes with infrastructure costs which are less than the SAM, and will apply only during the transition period to the new standard funding arrangements. For those homes with infrastructure costs below the SAM, the Commonwealth intends that the additional income gained as the infrastructure cost component of a home's fee is moved upwards to the SAM will be used to improve the quality of care provided, where this is not already at a satisfactory level. Where a home with unsatisfactory care standards receives an increase in infrastructure funding but does not use this additional income to improve care, it would be unjustifiable for that home to receive further increases in funding until the quality of care improves. Accordingly, the Bill gives the Minister the power to withhold increases in infrastructure funding until the home meets the gazetted care standards. Revenue lost would not be made up retrospectively in these cases even where the proprietor subsequently agrees to improve care standards.

The two additional powers are designed to indicate to providers that a persistent pattern of poor quality care will result in action being taken to protect nursing home residents. The use of these powers is seen as a more acceptable and workable approach to seeking compliance with the standards required.

Because of the desirability of involving industry, State government, consumer and professional interests in the monitoring of nursing home performance-nursing homes after all are community facilities which are of enormous significance in the care of our frail aged people-I propose to establish a peer review mechanism involving these groups to review recommendations to exercise the new powers.

Industry and consumer bodies have made the point in consultations regarding the new standards that any review and appeal mechanisms should be speedy and effective and be resourced with appropriately skilled professional and other suitably experienced personnel. Industry bodies have also rejected a remote and legalistic approach to solving the problems which arise when poor care practices are identified and have stressed the need for professional scrutiny in these areas. I have heeded those views and propose to create a nursing home standards review panel in each State and Territory. Discussions are to be held with State governments on the formation of these panels and it is likely at least one panel will be established on a pilot basis in the near future. The pilot should serve as a proving ground for this new approach and provide guidance on establishing similar bodies in other States.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The Minister's time has expired.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Porter

TALK.START.PARA: —On the understanding that the Government will allow the Opposition spokesman the same amount of time that the Minister takes, I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Minister for Community Services be granted an extension of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Certainly we will be very happy to allow the person leading for the Opposition about 35 minutes in which to speak. The Bill also introduces a new mechanism under the National Health Act 1953, in addition to the existing mechanism for the approval of applications for admission to an approved nursing home. This new mechanism will assist the Government in achieving its stated intention that only those who require the level of care available in a nursing home will be admitted to or remain in a nursing home. It has two elements. First, Commonwealth benefits will be payable only in respect of a person who is approved by the Minister as requiring nursing home care. Secondly, the Minister will have the power to reassess, at any time, a nursing home resident's need for nursing care and to stop payment of Commonwealth benefit in respect of that resident where the Minister determines that the resident no longer needs nursing home care and that other, more appropriate care is available.

SPEECH.PARA: This second mechanism recognises that a person's condition can change over time and that, for many people, admission to a nursing home need not be a one-way street. As a result of the specialised nursing care and, in some cases, rehabilitation provided in a nursing home, a person's condition-for example, in the case of a stroke-can improve to the point where that level of care is no longer needed. Such a person is likely to find the nursing home environment over-protected and dependency-creating, which could work against any further rehabilitation. Where it is found that a resident no longer requires nursing home care, he or she and any other appropriate people-for example, carers, relatives-will be counselled and given every assistance to find the necessary appropriate accommodation and support services.

In addition the length of time for which the approval of an application for admission to an approved nursing home remains valid will be limited. Where a person is not admitted to a nursing home within a specific period, and still wishes to be approved for admission purposes, that person will be required to have his or her need for nursing home care confirmed. These conditions will apply, in the longer term, to both Government and non-government nursing homes. However, a distinction is drawn in the Bill for the commencement of these measures in the case of government homes, as negotiations are currently occurring with State governments to set up the appropriate administrative mechanisms.

The Bill will also amend the current mechanism under the National Health Act 1953 for controlling the admission of people to approved nursing homes in emergency situations to ensure that such admissions are not used to subvert the normal admission control system. First, emergency admissions are to be notified as soon as practicable to allow the Minister or his delegate to establish that an emergency has occurred. Then, an application in accordance with the normal approval process is to be made within three working days, unless special circumstances exist which prevent the deadline from being met. This will ensure that a judgment as to whether the person was in need of nursing home care at the time of the emergency admission can reasonably be formed. Where an application made within the prescribed time period is approved, Commonwealth benefits will be payable from the date of admission. However, where an application is made outside the prescribed period and subsequently approved, Commonwealth benefits will be paid only from the date of approval.

The Bill will also make two amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954. The first of these amendments will enable the current value of donated land and other land acquired by an eligible organisation to be used in connection with an approved home under that Act, to be counted as part of the matching funds of the organisation. The second will enable provisions to be included in agreements entered into under the Act under which the Commonwealth may recover the value in real terms of a capital grant where the agreement has been breached.

Finally, during the Senate debate on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1986, the then Opposition spokesman on community services moved two amendments to omit `or otherwise' from new sub-sections 40ad (1ab) and 40ad (1ad) of the National Health Act 1953. My predecessor, Senator Grimes, undertook to seek and find an alternative way of wording these provisions, and on this basis the two amendments were withdrawn. This Bill therefore contains measures to remedy those perceived defects.

The new financial arrangements for nursing homes are expected to result in increased expenditure of $3m in 1987-88 and $14m in 1988-89. The other measures in the Bill have no readily quantifiable financial impact, although it is expected that there will be some very small savings in administrative costs. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 10 to 12 (1987).

The tariff proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 10 and 11 (1987) provide for the duty free entry of gas barbecues and parts thereof of New Zealand origin from 8 May 1986. The Australian and New Zealand governments have agreed that gas barbecues and parts thereof are not covered by the modified arrangement on whitegoods under the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement. Accordingly such goods should have been subject to the normal phasing arrangements of the agreement rather than being dutiable until 30 June 1987. The changes contained in these proposals provide duty free entry for the maximum period allowable under the relevant Customs refund provisions.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 12 (1987) implement changes arising from the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on vegetables and vegetable products and on the luggage, handbags and similar containers industry. These changes will operate on and from tomorrow.

In respect of the vegetables and vegetable products report, the Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that imports of fresh vegetables be dutiable at minimum rates and imports of processed vegetables be dutiable at a general tariff rate of 10 per cent. In addition, the Government has decided that fresh mushrooms will also become dutiable at a long term general tariff rate of 10 per cent. Where assistance will be significantly reduced, tariff reductions are to be phased in so as to give the relevant sectors adequate time to adjust.

In respect of the Commission's report on luggage, handbags and similar containers, the Government has decided on a uniform general tariff rate of 15 per cent for most of the goods which were under reference. A range of goods, including non-leather cases, trunks and handbags will be dutiable at a general tariff rate of 25 per cent until the end of this year. The general tariff rate on these goods will then phase to 20 per cent for all of 1988 and then to 15 per cent from 1 January 1989.

The general tariff rate for those goods currently dutiable at rates lower than 15 per cent will rise to 15 per cent from tomorrow. The uniform long term tariff treatment will assist in resolving classification problems that have previously provided incentives for substitution and reclassification.
Summaries of the alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated to honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.
